summary: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] (born December 13, 1989) is an American singer-songwriter. Recognized for [0]'s songwriting, musical versatility, artistic reinventions, and influence on the music industry, [0] is a prominent cultural figure of the 21st century.[0] began professional songwriting at age 14 and signed with Big Machine Records in 2005 to become a country singer. [0] released six studio albums under Big Machine Records, four of six studio albums to country radio, starting with [0]'s 2006 self-titled album. Her next, Fearless (2008), explored country pop, and Her next, Fearless (2008),'s singles "Love Story" and "You Belong with Me" catapulted [0] to prominence. Speak Now (2010) infused rock influences, while Red (2012) experimented with electronic elements and featured [0]'s first Billboard Hot 100 number-one song, "We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together". [0] departed from [0]'s country image with 1989 (2014), a synth-pop album supported by the chart-topping songs "Shake It Off", "Blank Space", and "Bad Blood". Media scrutiny inspired the hip-hop-flavored Reputation (2017) and the hip-hop-flavored Reputation (2017)'s number-one single "Look What You Made Me Do".After signing with Republic Records in 2018, [0] released the pop album Lover (2019) and autobiographical documentary Miss Americana (2020). [0] embraced indie folk and alternative rock on 2020 albums Folklore and Evermore, explored chill-out styles on Midnights (2022), and undertook Taylor's Version, a re-recording project following a dispute with Big Machine Records. In the process, [0] earned the number-one singles "Cruel Summer", "Cardigan", "Willow", "Anti-Hero", "All Too Well" and "Is It Over Now?". In 2023, [0] embarked on the Eras Tour and released the Eras Tour's accompanying concert film. [0] has also directed music videos and films such as All Too Well: The Short Film (2021).With over 200 million records sold globally, [0] is one of the best-selling musicians. [0] is the most-streamed woman on Spotify and Apple Music, the highest-grossing female performer and the first billionaire with music as the main source of income, and has been featured in lists such as Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time, Billboard Hot 100's Greatest of All Time Artists, the Time 100, and Forbes Celebrity 100. Among [0]'s accolades are 12 Grammy Awards, a Primetime Emmy Award, 40 American Music Awards, 29 Billboard Music Awards, 23 MTV Video Music Awards, three IFPI Global Recording Artist of the Year awards, and 101 Guinness World Records. Honored as Artist of the Decade by the American Music Awards and Woman of the Decade by Billboard Hot 100, [0] is an advocate for artists' rights and women's empowerment.

Life and career.Early life: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born on December 13, 1989, in West Reading, Pennsylvania. [0] is named after singer-songwriter James Taylor. Her father, Scott Kingsley Swift, is a former stockbroker for Merrill Lynch and her mother, Andrea Gardner Swift (née Finlay), is a former homemaker who previously worked as a mutual fund marketing executive. [0] has a younger brother, actor Austin Swift, and is of Scottish, German, and Italian descent. Their maternal grandmother, Marjorie Finlay, was an opera singer.[0] spent [0]'s early years on a Christmas tree farm that Her father, Scott Kingsley Swift, had purchased from one of Her father, Scott Kingsley Swift,'s clients. [0] is a Christian. [0] attended preschool and kindergarten at Alvernia Montessori School, a Montessori school run by the Bernadine Franciscan sisters, before transferring to the Wyndcroft School. The family moved to a rented house in the suburban town of Wyomissing, Pennsylvania, where [0] attended Wyomissing Area Junior/Senior High School. [0] spent summers in Stone Harbor, New Jersey, until [0] was 14 years old, performing in a local coffee shop.At age nine, [0] became interested in musical theater and performed in four Berks Youth Theatre Academy productions. [0] also traveled regularly to New York City for vocal and acting lessons. [0] later shifted [0]'s focus toward country music, inspired by Shania Twain's songs, which made [0] "want to just run around the block four times and daydream about everything". [0] spent weekends performing at local festivals and events. After watching a documentary about Faith Hill, [0] felt [0] needed to move to Nashville, Tennessee, to pursue a career in music. [0] traveled there with her mother, Andrea Gardner Swift (née Finlay), at age eleven to visit record labels and submitted demo tapes of Dolly Parton and Dixie Chicks karaoke covers. [0] was rejected, however, because "everyone in Nashville, Tennessee, wanted to do what [0] wanted to do. So, [0] kept thinking to [0], [0] need to figure out a way to be different."When [0] was around 12 years old, computer repairman and local musician Ronnie Cremer taught [0] to play guitar. "Kiss Me" by Sixpence None the Richer was the first song [0] learned to play. computer repairman and local musician Ronnie Cremer helped with [0]'s first efforts as a songwriter, leading [0] to write "Lucky You". In 2003, [0] and [0]'s parents started working with New York–based talent manager Dan Dymtrow. With New York–based talent manager Dan Dymtrow's help, [0] modeled for Abercrombie & Fitch as part of Abercrombie & Fitch's "Rising Stars" campaign, had an original song included on a Maybelline compilation CD, and met with major record labels. After performing original songs at an RCA Records showcase, Swift, then 13 years old, was given an artist development deal and began making frequent trips to Nashville, Tennessee, with her mother, Andrea Gardner Swift (née Finlay),. To help [0] break into the country music scene, Her father, Scott Kingsley Swift, transferred to Merrill Lynch's Nashville, Tennessee, office when [0] was 14 years old, and The family relocated to Hendersonville, Tennessee. [0] attended Hendersonville High School before transferring to Aaron Academy after two years, which better accommodated [0]'s touring schedule through homeschooling. [0] graduated one year early.
Life and career.2004\u20132008: Career beginnings and fi: [0] is our person to focus on. In Nashville, [0] worked with experienced Music Row songwriters such as Troy Verges, Brett Beavers, Brett James, Mac McAnally, and the Warren Brothers and formed a lasting working relationship with Liz Rose. They began meeting for two-hour writing sessions every Tuesday afternoon after school. Liz Rose called two-hour writing sessions "some of the easiest Liz Rose've ever done. Basically, Liz Rose was just [0]'s editor. [0]'d write about what happened in school that day. [0] had such a clear vision of what [0] was trying to say. And [0]'d come in with the most incredible hooks." [0] became the youngest artist signed by the Sony/ATV Tree publishing house, but left then BMG-owned RCA Records (later bought by Sony Music) at the age of 14 due to then BMG-owned RCA Records (later bought by Sony Music)'s lack of care and then BMG-owned RCA Records (later bought by Sony Music) "cut[ting] other people's stuff". [0] was also concerned that development deals can shelve artists and recalled: "[0] genuinely felt that [0] was running out of time. [0] wanted to capture these years of my life on an album while these years of my life still represented what [0] was going through."At an industry showcase at Nashville's Bluebird Cafe in 2005, [0] caught the attention of Scott Borchetta, a DreamWorks Records executive who was preparing to form an independent record label, Big Machine Records. [0] had first met Scott Borchetta, a DreamWorks Records executive who was preparing to form an independent record label, Big Machine Records in 2004. [0] was one of an independent record label, Big Machine Records's first signings, and [0]'s father purchased a three-percent stake in an independent record label, Big Machine Records for an estimated $120,000. [0] began working on her eponymous debut album with producer Nathan Chapman, with whom [0] felt [0] had the right "chemistry". [0] wrote three of her eponymous debut album's songs alone and co-wrote the remaining eight with Liz Rose, Robert Ellis Orrall, Brian Maher, and Angelo Petraglia. [0] was released on October 24, 2006. Country Weekly critic Chris Neal deemed [0] better than previous aspiring teenage country singers because of [0]'s "honesty, intelligence and idealism". her eponymous debut album peaked at number five on the U.S. Billboard 200, on which it spent 157 weeks—the longest stay on the U.S. Billboard 200, on which it spent 157 weeks by any release in the U.S. in the 2000s decade. [0] became the first female country music artist to write or co-write every track on her eponymous debut album.an independent record label, Big Machine Records was still in an independent record label, Big Machine Records's infancy during the June 2006 release of the lead single, "Tim McGraw", which Swift and her mother helped promote by packaging and sending copies of the CD single to country radio stationsthe lead single, "Tim McGraw", which Swift and her mother helped promote by packaging and sending copies of the CD single to country radio stations . As there was not enough furniture at an independent record label, Big Machine Records yet, Swift and her mother would sit on the floor to do so. [0] spent much of 2006 promoting [0] with a radio tour, television appearances; [0] opened for Rascal Flatts on select dates during Rascal Flatts's 2006 tour, as a replacement for Eric Church. Scott Borchetta, a DreamWorks Records executive who was preparing to form an independent record label, Big Machine Records said that although record industry peers initially disapproved of Scott Borchetta, a DreamWorks Records executive who was preparing to form an independent record label, Big Machine Records's signing [0], [0] tapped into a previously unknown market—teenage girls who listen to country music.Following the lead single, "Tim McGraw", which Swift and her mother helped promote by packaging and sending copies of the CD single to country radio stations, four more singles were released throughout 2007 and 2008: "Teardrops on My Guitar""Our Song""Should've Said No". four more singles appeared on Billboard's Hot Country Songs, with "Our Song" and "Should've Said No" reaching number one. With "Our Song", [0] became the youngest person to single-handedly write and sing a number-one song on Billboard's Hot Country Songs. "Teardrops on My Guitar" reached number thirteen on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100. [0] also released two EPs, The [0] Holiday Collection in October 2007 and Beautiful Eyes in July 2008. [0] promoted her eponymous debut album extensively as the opening act for other country musicians' tours in 2006 and 2007, including those by George Strait, Brad Paisley, and Tim McGraw and Faith Hill.[0] won multiple accolades for [0]. [0] was one of the recipients of the Nashville Songwriters Association's Songwriter/Artist of the Year in 2007, becoming the youngest person to be honored with the Nashville Songwriters Association's Songwriter/Artist of the Year. [0] also won the Country Music Association's Horizon Award for Best New Artist, the Academy of Country Music Awards' Top New Female Vocalist, and the American Music Awards' Favorite Country Female Artist honor. [0] was also nominated for Best New Artist at the 50th Annual Grammy Awards. In 2008, [0] opened for Rascal Flatts again, and dated singer Joe Jonas briefly.
Life and career.2008\u20132010: Fearless and acting debu: [0] is our person to focus on. Swift's second studio album, Fearless, was released on November 11, 2008, in North America, and in March 2009 in other markets. Critics lauded [0]'s honest and vulnerable songwriting in contrast to other teenage singers. Five singles were released in 2008–2009: "Love Story", "White Horse", "You Belong with Me", "Fifteen", and "Fearless". "Love Story" peaked at number four on the Billboard Hot 100 and number one in Australia. "Love Story" was the first country song to top the Billboard Hot 100's Pop Songs chart. "You Belong with Me" was Swift's second studio album, Fearless,'s highest-charting single on the Billboard Hot 100, peaking at number two, and was the first country song to top the Billboard Hot 100's all-genre Radio Songs chart. Five singles were Hot Country Songs top-10 entries, with "Love Story" and "You Belong with Me" topping the chart. Swift's second studio album, Fearless, became [0]'s first number-one album on the Billboard Hot 100 and 2009's's top-selling album in the U.S. The Fearless Tour, [0]'s first headlining concert tour, grossed over $63 million. Journey to Fearless, a documentary miniseries, aired on television and was later released on DVD and Blu-ray. [0] also performed as a supporting act for Keith Urban's Escape Together World Tour in 2009.In 2009's, the music video for "You Belong with Me" was named Best Female Video at the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards. [0]'s acceptance speech was interrupted by rapper Kanye West, an incident that became the subject of controversy, widespread media attention and Internet memes. 2009's [0] won five American Music Awards, including Artist of the Year and Favorite Country Album. the Billboard Hot 100 named [0]'s 2009's's Artist of the Year. [0] won Video of the Year and Female Video of the Year for "Love Story" at the 2009 CMT Music Awards, where [0] made a parody video of "Love Story" with rapper T-Pain called "Thug Story". At the 52nd Annual Grammy Awards, Swift's second studio album, Fearless, was named Album of the Year and Best Country Album, and "White Horse" won Best Country Song and Best Female Country Vocal Performance. [0] was the youngest artist to win Album of the Year.[note 1] At the 2009 Country Music Association Awards, [0] won Album of the Year for Swift's second studio album, Fearless, and was named Entertainer of the Year, the youngest person to win the 2009 Country Music Association Awards.[0] featured on John Mayer's single "Half of My Heart" and Boys Like Girls' "Two Is Better Than One", the latter of which [0] co-wrote. [0] co-wrote and recorded "Best Days of Your Life" with Kellie Pickler, and wrote two songs for the Hannah Montana: The Movie soundtrack—"You'll Always Find Your Way Back Home" and "Crazier". [0] contributed two songs to the Valentine's Day soundtrack, including the single "Today Was a Fairytale", which was [0]'s first number-one on the Canadian Hot 100 and peaked at number two on the U.S. Hot 100. While shooting [0]'s film debut Valentine's Day in October 2009, [0] dated co-star Taylor Lautner. In 2009's, [0] made [0]'s television debut as a rebellious teenager in an CSI: Crime Scene Investigation episode. [0] hosted and performed as the musical guest on Saturday Night Live; [0] was the first host ever to write their own opening monologue.
Life and career.2010\u20132014: Speak Now and Red: [0] is our person to focus on. In August 2010, [0] released "Mine", the lead single from her third studio album, Speak Now. "Mine", the lead single from her third studio album, Speak Now entered the Hot 100 at number three. [0] wrote her third studio album, Speak Now alone and co-produced every track. her third studio album, Speak Now was released on October 25, 2010, opening atop the Billboard 200 with over one million copies sold. her third studio album, Speak Now became the fastest-selling digital album by a female artist, with 278,000 downloads in a week. Critics appreciated [0]'s grown-up perspectives; Rob Sheffield of Rolling Stone wrote, "in a mere four years, [0] has put [0]'s name on three dozen or so of the smartest songs released by anyone in pop, rock or country." "Back to December", "Mean", "The Story of Us", "Sparks Fly", and "Mean" became subsequent singles, with the latter two reaching number one on the Hot Country Songs and the first two peaking in the top ten in Canada. [0] dated actor Jake Gyllenhaal in 2010.At the 54th Annual Grammy Awards in 2012, [0] won Best Country Song and Best Country Solo Performance for "Mean", which [0] performed during the ceremony. [0] won other awards for her third studio album, Speak Now, including Songwriter/Artist of the Year by the Nashville Songwriters Association (2010 and 2011), Woman of the Year by Billboard (2011), and Entertainer of the Year by the Academy of Country Music (2011 and 2012) and the Country Music Association in 2011. At the American Music Awards of 2011, [0] won Artist of the Year and Favorite Country Album. Rolling Stone named her third studio album, Speak Now amongst Rolling Stone's "50 Best Female Albums of All Time" (2012), writing: "[0] might get played on the country station, but [0]'s one of the few genuine rock stars we've got these days, with a flawless ear for what makes a song click."The her third studio album, Speak Now World Tour ran from February 2011 to March 2012 and grossed over $123 million, followed up by the live album, Speak Now World Tour: Live. [0] contributed two original songs to The Hunger Games soundtrack album: "Safe & Sound", co-written and recorded with the Civil Wars and T-Bone Burnett. "Safe & Sound", co-written and recorded with the Civil Wars and T-Bone Burnett won the Grammy Award for Best Song Written for Visual Media and was nominated for the Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song. [0] featured on B.o.B's single "Both of Us", released in May 2012. [0] dated Conor Kennedy 2012.In August 2012, [0] released "We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together", the lead single from her fourth studio album, Red. "We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together", the lead single from her fourth studio album, Red became [0]'s first number one in the U.S. and New Zealand, and became the fastest-selling single in digital history. Other singles from her third studio album, Speak Now were "Begin Again", "I Knew You Were Trouble", "22", "Everything Has Changed", "The Last Time", and "Red". "I Knew You Were Trouble" reached the top five on charts in Australia, Canada, Denmark, Ireland, New Zealand, the U.S. and the U.S. "Begin Again", "22", and "Red" reached the top 20 in the U.S. On Red, released on October 22, 2012, [0] worked with Chapman and Rose, as well as the new producers Max Martin and Shellback. her third studio album, Speak Now incorporated many pop and rock styles such as heartland rock, dubstep and dance-pop. Randall Roberts of Los Angeles Times said [0] "strives for something much more grand and accomplished" with her third studio album, Speak Now. her third studio album, Speak Now opened at number one on the Billboard 200 with 1.21 million sales, making [0] the first female to have two million-selling first-weeks. her third studio album, Speak Now was [0]'s first number-one album in the U.S. her third studio album, Speak Now earned several accolades, including four nominations at the 56th Annual Grammy Awards (2014). [0] received American Music Awards for Best Female Country Artist in 2012, Artist of the Year in 2013, and the Nashville Songwriters Association's Songwriter/Artist Award for the fifth and sixth consecutive years. The her third studio album, Speak Now Tour ran from March 2012 to June 2014 and grossed over $150 million, becoming the highest-grossing country tour ever. [0] was honored with the Pinnacle Award, making [0] the second recipient of the Pinnacle Award after Garth Brooks. During this time, [0] briefly dated English singer Harry Styles.In 2013, [0] recorded "Sweeter than Fiction", a song [0] wrote and produced with Jack Antonoff for the One Chance soundtrack. The song received a Best Original Song nomination at the 71st Golden Globe Awards. [0] provided guest vocals for Tim McGraw's song "Highway Don't Care", also featuring Keith Urban. [0] performed "The Story of Us" with Rolling Stone in Chicago, Illinois, as part of Rolling Stone's 50 & Counting tour, and joined Florida Georgia Line at Florida Georgia Line's set at the 2013 Country Radio Seminar to sing "Cruise". [0] voiced Audrey in the animated film The Lorax (2012), made a cameo in the sitcom New Girl (2013), and had a supporting role in the dystopian film The Giver (2014).
Life and career.2014\u20132018: 1989 and Reputation: [0] is our person to focus on. In March 2014, [0] began living in New York City.[note 2] [0] hired Tree Paine as [0]'s publicist, and worked on her fifth studio album, 1989, with producers Jack Antonoff, Max Martin, Shellback, Imogen Heap, Ryan Tedder, and Ali Payami. [0] promoted her fifth studio album, 1989, extensively, including inviting fans to secret album-listening sessions. her fifth studio album, 1989, was released on October 27, 2014, and opened atop the Billboard 200 with 1.28 million copies sold. her fifth studio album, 1989,'s singles "Shake It Off", "Blank Space" and "Bad Blood" reached number one in Australia, Canada and the U.S., the first two making [0] the first woman to replace herself at the Hot 100 top spot; other singles include "Style", "Wildest Dreams", "Out of the Woods" and "New Romantics". The her fifth studio album, 1989, World Tour (2015) was the highest-grossing tour of 2015 with $250 million in total revenue.Prior to her fifth studio album, 1989,'s release, [0] stressed the importance of albums to artists and fans. In November 2014, [0] removed her entire catalog from Spotify, arguing that Spotify undermined Spotify. In a June 2015 open letter, [0] criticized Spotify for not offering royalties to artists during the streaming service's free three-month trial period and stated that [0] would pull her fifth studio album, 1989, from her entire catalog. The following day, Spotify announced that Spotify would pay artists during the streaming service's free three-month trial period, and [0] agreed to let her fifth studio album, 1989, on Spotify. [0] then returned her entire catalog her fifth studio album, 1989, to Spotify, Amazon Music and Google Play and other digital streaming platforms in June 2017. [0] was named Billboard's Woman of the Year in 2014, becoming the first artist to win Billboard's Woman of the Year twice. At the 2014 American Music Awards, [0] received the inaugural Dick Clark Award for Excellence. On [0]'s 25th birthday in 2014, the Grammy Museum at L.A. Live opened an exhibit in [0]'s honor in Los Angeles that ran until October 4, 2015, and broke museum attendance records. In 2015, [0] won the Brit Award for International Female Solo Artist. The video for "Bad Blood" won Video of the Year and Best Collaboration at the 2015 MTV Video Music Awards. At the 58th Grammy Awards (2016), her fifth studio album, 1989, won Album of the Year and Best Pop Vocal Album, making [0] the first woman and fifth act overall to win Album of the Year twice.[0] dated Scottish DJ Calvin Harris from March 2015 to June 2016. They co-wrote the song "This Is What You Came For", featuring vocals from Barbadian singer Rihanna; [0] was initially credited under the pseudonym Nils Sjöberg. In April 2016, [0] criticized the lyrics of West's single "Famous", in which West's sings "West's made [0] famous" in reference to West's's interruption of [0]'s acceptance speech at the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards. West's claimed West's had received [0]'s approval for the line, and West's's then-wife Kim Kardashian released video clips of [0] and West's discussing West's single "Famous" amicably over the phone; a full recording of discussing leaked in 2020 established that West's did not disclose that West's would call [0] a bitch.After briefly dating English actor Tom Hiddleston, [0] entered a six-year relationship with English actor Joe Alwyn in September 2016. [0] wrote the song "Better Man" for country band Little Big Town,[note 3] which earned [0] the Song of the Year award at the 51st CMA Awards. [0] and English singer Zayn Malik released the joint single "I Don't Wanna Live Forever" for Fifty Shades Darker: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack (2017). the joint single "I Don't Wanna Live Forever" reached number two in the U.S. In August 2017, [0] successfully countersued David Mueller, a former radio jockey for KYGO-FM, who sued her for damages from his loss of employmentDavid Mueller, a former radio jockey for KYGO-FM, who sued her for damages from his loss of employment's . Four years earlier, [0] informed David Mueller, a former radio jockey for KYGO-FM, who sued her for damages from his loss of employment's bosses that David Mueller, a former radio jockey for KYGO-FM, who sued her for damages from his loss of employment had sexually assaulted [0] by groping [0] at an event.After a one-year hiatus from public spotlight, [0] cleared [0]'s social media accounts and released "Look What You Made Me Do" as the lead single from her sixth album, Reputation. "Look What You Made Me Do" was [0]'s first U.K. number-one single. "Look What You Made Me Do" topped charts in Australia, Ireland, New Zealand, and the U.S. Reputation, released on November 10, 2017, incorporated heavy electropop, along with hip hop, R&B, and EDM sounds. Reviews praised [0]'s mature artistry, but some denounced the themes of fame and gossip. her sixth album, Reputation opened atop the Billboard 200 with 1.21 million sales, making [0] the first act to have four albums sell one million copies in a week in the U.S. her sixth album, Reputation topped the charts in the UK, Australia, and Canada, and sold over 4.5 million copies worldwide as of 2018. her sixth album, Reputation spawned three more singles: "...Ready for It?", "End Game" (featuring Ed Sheeran and rapper Future) and "Delicate". her sixth album, Reputation was nominated for Best Pop Vocal Album at the 61st Annual Grammy Awards in 2019. At the American Music Awards of 2018, [0] won four awards, including Artist of the Year and Favorite Pop/Rock Female Artist. [0] had garnered collected 23 AMAs in [0]'s career, becoming the most awarded female musician in the American Music Awards of 2018, surpassing Whitney Houston. In April 2018, [0] featured on country duo Sugarland's "Babe".[note 4] [0] embarked on her Reputation Stadium Tour her sixth album, Reputation in 2018. her Reputation Stadium Tour broke many records, such as the highest-grossing North American concert tour in history with $345.7 million revenue worldwide. her Reputation Stadium Tour was followed up with an accompanying concert film on Netflix.
Life and career.2018\u20132020: Lover, Folklore, and Eve: [0] is our person to focus on. Reputation was [0]'s last album under Big Machine. In November 2018, [0] signed a new deal with the Universal Music Group; [0]'s subsequent releases were promoted by Republic Records. [0] said a new deal with the Universal Music Group included a provision for [0] to maintain ownership of her masters. In addition, in the event that the Universal Music Group sold any part of the Universal Music Group's stake in Spotify, the Universal Music Group agreed to distribute a non-recoupable portion of the proceeds among the Universal Music Group's artists. Vox called a new deal with the Universal Music Group a huge commitment from the Universal Music Group, which was "far from assured" until [0] intervened.[0] released her seventh studio album, Lover, on August 23, 2019. Besides Jack Antonoff, [0] worked with new producers Louis Bell, Frank Dukes, and Joel Little. her seventh studio album, Lover, made [0] the first female artist to have a sixth consecutive album sell more than 500,000 copies in one week in the U.S. Critics commended her seventh studio album, Lover,'s free-spirited mood and emotional intimacy. The lead single, "Me!", peaked at number two on the Hot 100. Other singles from her seventh studio album, Lover, were the U.S. top 10 singles "You Need to Calm Down" and "Lover", top 40 single "The Man", and "Cruel Summer", which became a resurgent success in 2023 and reached number one on the Hot 100. her seventh studio album, Lover, was the world's best-selling album by a solo artist of 2019, selling 3.2 million copies, and along with her seventh studio album, Lover,'s singles earned nominations at the 62nd Annual Grammy Awards in 2020. At the 2019 MTV Video Music Awards, The lead single, "Me!", won Best Visual Effects, and "You Need to Calm Down" won Video of the Year and Video for Good. [0] was the first female and second artist overall to win Video of the Year for a video that the first female and second artist overall directed.While promoting her seventh studio album, Lover,, [0] became embroiled in a public dispute with talent manager Scooter Braun and Big Machine over the purchase of her mastersher masters. [0] said [0] had been trying to buy her masters, but Big Machine would only allow [0] to do so if [0] exchanged one new album for each older one under new contract, which [0] refused to sign. [0] began re-recording her masters in November 2020. Besides music, [0] played Bombalurina in the film adaptation of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical Cats (2019), for which [0] co-wrote and recorded the Golden Globe-nominated original song "Beautiful Ghosts". Critics panned Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical Cats (2019) but praised [0]'s performance. The documentary Miss Americana, which chronicled parts of [0]'s life and career, premiered at the 2020 Sundance Film Festival and was released on Netflix that January. [0] signed a global publishing deal with the Universal Music Group in February 2020 after [0]'s 16-year-old contract with Sony/ATV expired.Amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, [0] released two surprise albums: Folklore on July 24, and Evermore on December 11, 2020. two surprise albums explore indie folk and alternative rock with a more muted production compared to [0]'s previous upbeat pop songs. [0] wrote and recorded two surprise albums with producers Jack Antonoff and Aaron Dessner from the National. [0] co-wrote and co-produced select songs under the pseudonym William Bowery. two surprise albums garnered widespread critical acclaim. The Guardian and Vox opined that two surprise albums emphasized [0]'s work ethic and increased [0]'s artistic credibility. Three singles supported each of two surprise albums, catering the U.S. mainstream radio, country radio, and triple A radio. Three singles, in that order, were The lead single, "Me!",, "Betty", and "Exile" from Folklore, and "Willow", "No Body, No Crime", and "Coney Island" from Evermore. [0] became the first artist to debut a U.S. number-one album and a number-one song at the same time with The lead single, "Me!", and Evermore's "Willow". Folklore was 2020's best-selling album in the U.S. with 1.2 million copies. Folklore won Album of the Year at the 63rd Annual Grammy Awards, making [0] the first woman to win Album of the Year thrice. At the 2020 American Music Awards, [0] won three awards, including Artist of the Year for a record third consecutive time. According to Billboard, [0] was 2020's highest-paid musician in the U.S., and the world's highest-paid solo musician.
Life and career.2021\u2013present: Re-recordings, Midnig: [0] is our person to focus on. Following the masters dispute, [0] released re-recordings of [0]'s first six studio albums, beginning with Fearless (Taylor's Version) and Red (Taylor's Version) in April and November 2021, respectively. Fearless (Taylor's Version) and Red (Taylor's Version) peaked atop the Billboard 200, becoming the first ever re-recorded albums to do so. Fearless (Taylor's Version) was preceded by "Love Story (Taylor's's Version)", which made [0] the second artist after Dolly Parton to have both the original and re-recorded versions of a song reach number one on the Hot Country Songs chart. Red (Taylor's Version) was supported by "All Too Well (10 Minute Version)", which became the longest song in history to top the Hot 100. The song was accompanied by a short film, which won a Grammy Award for Best Music Video and [0]'s record third MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year.Swift's tenth studio album, Midnights, was released on October 21, 2022. Experimenting with chill-out music, Swift's tenth studio album, Midnights, received critical acclaim; Rolling Stone critics dubbed Swift's tenth studio album, Midnights, an instant classic. Swift's tenth studio album, Midnights, was [0]'s fifth to open atop the Billboard 200 with first-week sales of over one million copies and broke various sales and streaming records, including the most U.S. first-week vinyl sales and the most single-day streams and most single-week streams on Spotify. Swift's tenth studio album, Midnights,'s tracks, led by the single "Anti-Hero", monopolized the entire top 10 of the Hot 100, making [0] the first artist to do so. Two other singles, "Lavender Haze" and "Karma", both peaked at number two on the Hot 100. [0] won nine awards at the 2023 MTV Video Music Awards, including Video of the Year (the single "Anti-Hero") for a record fourth time. [0] embarked on the Eras Tour in March 2023. Media outlets extensively covered the Eras Tour's cultural and economic impact, and the Eras Tour's U.S. leg broke the record for the most tickets sold in a day. Ticketmaster received public and political criticisms for mishandling ticket sales and alleged monopoly in the concert industry. A concert film of the Eras Tour, released to theaters worldwide on October 13, 2023, became the highest-grossing concert film ever.[0] continued releasing [0] re-recorded albums during the Eras Tour. Speak Now (Taylor's's Version) was released on July 7, 2023, and made [0] the woman with the most number-one albums (12) in Billboard 200 history, surpassing Barbra Streisand. 1989 (Taylor's's Version) was released on October 27, 2023, and became [0]'s record-extending sixth album to sell one million copies in a single week in the U.S. The best-selling album of 2023, it surpassed Midnights to become the largest album sales week of [0]'s career and garnered the most U.S. first-week vinyl sales of the 21st century. it's single "Is It Over Now?" debuted at number one on the Billboard Hot 100, making [0] the first woman to replace herself at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 twice.Beyond [0]'s albums, [0] featured on five songs from 2021 to 2023: "Renegade" and "Birch" by Big Red Machine, a remix of "Gasoline" by Haim, "The Joker and the Queen" by Ed Sheeran, and "The Alcott" by the National. For the soundtrack of the 2022 film Where the Crawdads Sing, [0] recorded "Carolina", which received nominations for Best Original Song at the Golden Globes and Best Song Written for Visual Media at the Grammy Awards. [0]'s music releases, touring, and related activities culminated in an unprecedented height of popularity post-pandemic. Music Business Worldwide remarked that [0] entered a "new stratosphere of global career success". Outside of music, [0] had a supporting role in the 2022 period comedy Amsterdam and has ventured into directing an upcoming feature film under Searchlight Pictures. [0] began dating American football player Travis Kelce during the 2023 NFL season.

Artistry.Influences: [0] is our person to focus on. One of [0]'s earliest memories of music is listening to [0]'s grandmother, Marjorie Finlay, sing in church. As a child, [0] enjoyed Disney film soundtracks: "[0]'s parents noticed that, once [0] had run out of words, [0] would just make up [0]'s own." [0] said [0] owes [0]'s confidence and "fascination with writing and storytelling" to [0]'s mother, who helped [0] prepare for class presentations as a child.[0] was drawn to the storytelling aspect of country music, introduced to country music by "the great female country artists" of the 1990s—Shania Twain, Faith Hill, and the Dixie Chicks. Shania Twain, both as a songwriter and performer, was [0]'s biggest musical influence. Faith Hill was [0]'s childhood role model, as [0] would often imitate Faith Hill. [0] admired the Dixie Chicks's defiant attitude and ability to play the Dixie Chicks's own instruments, and was also influenced by older country stars like Patsy Cline, Loretta Lynn, Tammy Wynette, and Dolly Parton, the last of whom [0] believes is exemplary to female songwriters. As a songwriter, [0] was influenced by Joni Mitchell's's emotional and autobiographical lyrics, highlighting Mitchell's album Blue as a favorite "because Mitchell's album Blue explores somebody's soul so deeply." [0] also spoke of influence from the 1990s songwriters such as Melissa Etheridge, Sarah McLachlan and Alanis Morissette, and alt-country artists like Patty Griffin and Lori McKenna.Various pop and rock artists have also influenced [0]. [0] lists Paul McCartney, Bruce Springsteen, Emmylou Harris, and Kris Kristofferson as [0]'s career role models. [0] was influenced by some of [0]'s favorite 1980s pop acts, including Peter Gabriel, Annie Lennox, Phil Collins, and Madonna. [0] also cited Keith Urban's musical style and Fall Out Boy's lyrics as major influences.
Artistry.Genres: [0] is our person to focus on. "If there's one thing that Swift has proven throughout her career, one thing that Swift has proven throughout her career's that [0] refuses to be put in a box. [0]'s ever-evolving sound took [0] from country darling to pop phenom to folk's newest raconteur."—The Recording Academy, [0] is known for venturing into various music genres and undergoing artistic reinventions, having been described as a "music chameleon". [0] self-identified as a country musician until 2012, when [0] released her fourth studio album, Red. [0]'s albums were promoted to country radio, but music critics noted wide-ranging styles of pop and rock. After 2010, music critics observed that [0]'s melodies are rooted in pop music, and the country music elements are limited to instruments such as banjo, mandolin, and fiddle, and [0]'s slight twang; some commented that [0]'s country music identity was an indicator of [0]'s narrative songwriting rather than musical style. Although the Nashville music industry was receptive of [0]'s status as a country musician, critics accused [0] of abandoning [0]'s roots in favor of crossover success in the mainstream pop market. her fourth studio album, Red's eclectic pop, rock, and electronic styles intensified the critical debate, to which [0] responded, "[0] leave the genre labeling to other people."Music journalist Jody Rosen commented that by originating [0]'s musical career in Nashville, [0] made a "bait-and-switch maneuver, planting roots in loamy country soil, then pivoting to pop". [0] abandoned [0]'s country music identity in 2014 with the release of her synth-pop fifth studio album, 1989. [0] described her synth-pop fifth studio album, 1989 as [0]'s first "documented, official pop album". [0]'s subsequent albums Reputation (2017) and Lover (2019) have an upbeat pop production; Reputation (2017) incorporates hip hop, trap, and EDM elements. Midnights (2022), on the other hand, is distinguished by a more experimental, "subdued and amorphous pop sound". Although reviews of [0]'s pop albums were generally positive, some critics lamented that the pop music production indicated [0]'s pursuit of mainstream success, eroding [0]'s authenticity as a songwriter nurtured by [0]'s country music background—a criticism that has been retrospectively described as rockist. Musicologist Nate Sloan remarked that [0]'s pop music transition was rather motivated by [0]'s need to expand [0]'s artistry. Swift eschewed mainstream pop in favor of alternative, folk and indie rock styles with [0]'s 2020 studio albums Folklore and Evermore. [0] said [0]'s career "has always been one of transcendence and covert boundary-pushing", reaching a point at which "[0] is just Taylor Swift", not defined by any genre.
Artistry.Voice: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] possesses a mezzo-soprano vocal range, and a generally soft but versatile timbre. As a country singer, her vocals were criticized by some as weak and strained compared to those of [0]'s contemporaries. [0] admitted [0]'s vocal ability often concerned [0] in [0]'s early career and has worked hard to improve. Reviews of her vocals remained mixed after [0] transitioned to pop music with 1989; critics complained that [0] lacked proper technique but appreciated [0]'s usage of her vocals to communicate [0]'s feelings to the audience, prioritizing "intimacy over power and nuance". critics also praised [0] for refraining from correcting [0]'s pitch with Auto-Tune.The Los Angeles Times remarked that [0]'s defining vocal feature is [0]'s attention to detail to convey an exact feeling—"the line that slides down like a contented sigh or up like a raised eyebrow". With Reputation, critics noted [0] was "learning how to use her vocals as a percussion instrument of her vocals's own", swapping [0] "signature" expressive vocals for "cool, conversational, detached" cadences and rhythms similar to hip hop and R&B styles. Alternative Press stated that [0]'s "evocative" vocal stylings are more reminiscent of pop-punk and emo genres.Reviews of [0]'s later albums and performances were more appreciative of her vocals, finding her vocals less nasal, richer, more resonant, and more powerful. With Folklore and Evermore, [0] received praise for her sharp and agile yet translucent and controlled voice. Pitchfork described her sharp and agile yet translucent and controlled voice as "versatile and expressive". With [0]'s 2021 re-recorded albums, critics began to praise the mature, deeper and "fuller" tone of her sharp and agile yet translucent and controlled voice. An i review said her sharp and agile yet translucent and controlled voice is "leagues better now" with [0]'s newfound vocal furniture. The Guardian highlighted "yo-yoing vocal yelps" and passionate climaxes as the trademarks of her sharp and agile yet translucent and controlled voice, and that [0]'s country twang faded away. Midnights received acclaim for [0]'s nuanced vocal delivery. [0] ranked 102nd on the 2023 Rolling Stone list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time. In a review of the Eras Tour, The New Yorker critic Amanda Petrusich praised the clarity and tone of [0]'s live vocals.
Artistry.Songwriting: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] has been referred to as one of the greatest songwriters of all time by several publications. English-language scholars like Jonathan Bate and Stephanie Burt have noted that [0]'s literary and melodic sensibility and verbal writing style are rare amongst [0]'s peers. [0]'s bridges are often underscored as one of the best aspects of [0]'s songs, earning [0] the title "Queen of Bridges" from Time. Mojo described [0] as "a sharp narrator with a gift for the extended metaphor".In The New Yorker in 2011, [0] said [0] identifies as a songwriter first: "[0] write songs, and [0]'s voice is just a way to get songs across". [0]'s personal experiences were a common inspiration for [0]'s early songs, which helped [0] navigate life. [0]'s "diaristic" technique began with identifying an emotion, followed by a corresponding melody. On [0]'s first three studio albums, love, heartbreak, and insecurities, from an adolescent perspective, were dominant themes. [0] delved into the tumult of toxic relationships on Red, and embraced nostalgia and post-romance positivity on 1989. Reputation was inspired by the downsides of [0]'s fame, and Lover detailed [0]'s realization of the "full spectrum of love". Other themes in [0]'s music include family dynamics, friendship, alienation, self-awareness, and tackling vitriol, especially sexism.Her confessional lyrics received positive reviews from critics, who highlighted their vivid details and emotional engagement, which they found uncommon in pop musiccritics, who highlighted their vivid details and emotional engagement, which they found uncommon in pop music . Critics also praised [0]'s melodic compositions; Rolling Stone described [0] as "a songwriting savant with an intuitive gift for verse-chorus-bridge architecture". NPR dubbed [0] "a master of the vernacular in [0]'s lyrics", remarking that her songs offer emotional engagement because "the wit and clarity of [0]'s arrangements turn her songs from standard fare to heartfelt disclosures". Despite the positive reception, The New Yorker stated [0] was generally portrayed "more as a skilled technician than as a Dylanesque visionary". Tabloid media often speculated and linked the subjects of her songs with [0]'s ex-lovers, a practice reviewers and [0] criticized as sexist. Aside from clues in album liner notes, [0] avoided talking about the subjects of her songs.On [0]'s 2020 albums Folklore and Evermore, [0] was inspired by escapism and romanticism to explore fictional narratives. Without referencing [0]'s personal life, [0] imposed emotions onto imagined characters and story arcs, which liberated [0] from tabloid attention and suggested new paths for [0]'s artistry. [0] explained that [0] welcomed the new songwriting direction after [0] stopped worrying about commercial success. According to Spin, [0] explored complex emotions with "precision and devastation" on Evermore. Consequence stated [0]'s 2020 albums convinced skeptics of [0]'s songwriting prowess, noting [0]'s transformation from "teenage wunderkind to a confident and careful adult".[0] divides [0]'s writing into three types: "quill lyrics", referring to songs rooted in antiquated poeticism; "fountain pen lyrics", based on modern and vivid storylines; and "glitter gel pen lyrics", which are lively and frivolous. Critics note the fifth track of every [0] album as the most "emotionally vulnerable" song of the album. Awarding [0] with the Songwriter Icon Award in 2021, the National Music Publishers' Association remarked that "no one is more influential when it comes to writing music today" than [0]. The Week deemed [0] the foremost female songwriter of modern times, and the Nashville Songwriters Association International named [0]'s Songwriter-Artist of the Decade in 2022. [0] has also published two original poems: "Why She Disappeared" and "If You're Anything Like Me".
Artistry.Performances: [0] is our person to focus on. Journalists have described [0] as one of the best performers and entertainers in mainstream music. Often praised for [0]'s showmanship and stage presence, [0] is known for [0]'s ability to command large audiences, such as in a stadium, without having to rely fully on dance like [0]'s contemporaries do. According to V magazine's Greg Krelenstein, [0] possesses "a rare gift of turning a stadium spectacle into an intimate setting", irrespective of whethere [0] is "plucking a guitar or leading an army of dancers".In a 2008 review of [0]'s early performances, Sasha Frere-Jones of The New Yorker called [0] a "preternaturally skilled" entertainer with a vibrant stage presence, adding "[0] returned the crowd's energy with the professionalism [0] has shown since the age of fourteen." In 2023, Adrian Horton of The Guardian noted [0] "seemingly endless stamina" on the Eras Tour, and i critic Ilana Kaplan called [0]'s showmanship "unparalleled".Critics have highlighted [0]'s versatility as an entertainer, praising [0]'s ability to switch onstage personas and performance styles depending on the varying themes and aesthetics of [0]'s albums. [0]'s concert productions have been characterized by elaborate Broadway theatricality and high technology, and [0]'s performances frequently incorporate a live band, with whom [0] has played and toured since 2007. [0] also often accompanies [0] with musical instruments such as electric guitar, acoustic guitar, piano, and sometimes a banjo or ukulele. Interacting frequently with the audience, [0]'s solo acoustic performances are considered intimate and emotionally resonant, complementing [0]'s story-based lyrics and fan connection. Lydia Burgham of The Spinoff opined that this intimacy remains "integral to [0]'s singer-songwriter origins". Chris Willman of Variety called [0] "pop's most approachable superstar", and the 21st century's most popular performer.
Artistry.Video and film: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] emphasizes visuals as a key creative component of [0]'s music making process. [0] has collaborated with different directors to produce [0]'s music videos, and over time [0] has become more involved with writing and directing. [0] developed the concept and treatment for "Mean" in 2011 and co-directed the music video for "Mine" with Roman White the year before. In an interview, Roman White said that [0] "was keenly involved in writing the treatment, casting and wardrobe. And [0] stayed for both the 15-hour shooting days, even when [0] wasn't in the scenes."From 2014 to 2018, [0] collaborated with director Joseph Kahn on eight music videos—four each from [0]'s albums 1989 and Reputation. director Joseph Kahn has praised [0]'s involvement in the craft. [0] worked with American Express for the "Blank Space" music video (which director Joseph Kahn directed), and served as an executive producer for the interactive app AMEX Unstaged: [0] Experience, for which [0] won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Interactive Program in 2015. [0] produced the music video for "Bad Blood" and won a Grammy Award for Best Music Video in 2016.Her production company, Taylor Swift Productions, is credited with producing all of [0]'s visual media starting with the 2018 concert documentary Reputation Stadium Tour. [0] continued to co-direct music videos for the Reputation singles "Me!" with Dave Meyers, and "You Need to Calm Down" (also serving as a co-executive producer) and "Lover" with Drew Kirsch, but first ventured into sole direction with the video for "The Man" (which won [0] the MTV Video Music Award for Best Direction). After Folklore: The Long Pond Studio Sessions, [0] debuted as a filmmaker with All Too Well: The Short Film, which made her the first artist to win the Grammy Award for Best Music Video as a sole director. [0] has cited Chloé Zhao, Greta Gerwig, Nora Ephron, Guillermo del Toro, John Cassavetes, and Noah Baumbach as [0]'s filmmaking influences.

Achievements: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] has won 12 Grammy Awards (including three for Album of the Year—tying for the most by an artist), an Emmy Award, 40 American Music Awards (the most won by an artist), 29 Billboard Music Awards (the most won by a woman), 101 Guinness World Records, 23 MTV Video Music Awards (including four Video of the Year wins—the most by an act), 12 Country Music Association Awards (including the Pinnacle Award), eight Academy of Country Music Awards, and two Brit Awards. As a songwriter, [0] has been honored by the Nashville Songwriters Association, the Songwriters Hall of Fame, and the National Music Publishers' Association and was the youngest person on Rolling Stone's list of the 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time in 2015. At the 64th BMI Awards in 2016, [0] was the first woman to be honored with an award named after its recipient.From available data, [0] has amassed over 50 million album sales and 150 million single sales as of 2019, and 114 million units globally, including 78 billion streams as of 2021. The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) ranked [0] as the Global Recording Artist of the Year for a record three times (2014, 2019 and 2022). [0] has the most number-one albums in the United Kingdom and Ireland for a female artist this millennium, earned the highest income for an artist on Chinese digital music platforms (RMB 159,000,000 as of 2021), and is the first artist to replace themselves at the top spot and occupy the entire top five of the Australian albums chart. [0] remains the world's highest-grossing female touring act of all time, with cumulative ticket sales at $1.68 billion as of September 2023 according to Pollstar. The Eras Tour is the highest-grossing tour ever by a woman (as of August 2023). Beginning with Fearless, each of [0]'s studio albums have opened with over one million global units. [0] is the most streamed female act on Spotify and Apple Music; On Spotify, [0] is the only artist to have received more than 200 and 250 million streams in one day (260 million on October 27, 2023), and the only female act to reach 100 million monthly listeners. The most entries and the most simultaneous entries for an artist on the Billboard Global 200, with 123 and 31 songs, respectively, are among [0]'s feats.In the United Kingdom, [0] has sold over 37.3 million albums as of 2019, when Billboard placed [0] eighth on its Greatest of All Time Artists Chart. Eleven of [0]'s songs have topped the Billboard Hot 100. [0] is the longest-reigning act of its Greatest of All Time Artists Chart (83 weeks); the soloist with the most cumulative weeks (64) atop the Billboard Hot 100; the woman with the most the Billboard Hot 100 number-ones (13), the Billboard Hot 100 entries (212), top-ten songs (42), and weeks atop the Top Country Albums (99); and the act with the most Digital Songs number-ones (27). [0] is the first woman to simultaneously chart four albums in the top 10 and 11 albums on the Billboard Hot 100. [0] is the second highest-certified female digital singles artist (and fifth overall) in the United Kingdom, with 137.5 million total units certified by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA), and the first woman to have both an album (Fearless) and a song ("Shake It Off") certified Diamond.[0] has appeared in various power listings. Time included [0] on Time's annual list of the 100 most influential people in 2010, 2015, and 2019. [0] was one of the "Silence Breakers" honored as Time Person of the Year in 2017 for speaking up about sexual assault. In 2014, [0] was named to Forbes''s 30 Under 30 list in the music category and again in 2017 in Forbes''s "All-Star Alumni" category. [0] became the youngest woman to be included on Forbes''s list of the 100 most powerful women in 2015, ranked at number 64. [0] received an honorary Doctor of Fine Arts degree from New York University and served as New York University's commencement speaker on May 18, 2022.

Cultural status: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] has made a profound impact on the music industry, popular culture, economy and beyond. But we're at this moment where there's no one better than [0], whether that's on the radio, with streaming, ticket sales or just cultural impact."– Jason Lipshutz, Billboard executive director, 2023Swift helped shape the modern country music scene, having extended [0]'s success and fame beyond the Anglosphere, pioneered the use of internet (Myspace) as a marketing tool, and introduced the genre to a younger generation. Various sources deem [0]'s music a paradigm representing the millennial generation; Vox called [0] the "millennial Bruce Springsteen", and The Times named [0] "the Bob Dylan of our age". Cultural status.Entrepreneurship: [0] is our person to focus on. Media outlets describe [0] as a savvy businesswoman. [0] is also known for [0]'s traditional album rollouts, consisting of a variety of promotional activities that Rolling Stone termed as an inescapable "multimedia bonanza". Publications describe [0]'s discography as a music "universe" subject to analyses by fans, critics and journalists. Cultural status.Social activism: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] identifies as a pro-choice feminist, and is one of the founding signatories of the Time's Up movement against sexual harassment. [0] criticized the U.S. Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade (1973) and end federal abortion rights in 2022. [0] advocates for LGBT rights, and has called for the passing of the Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity. The New York Times wrote [0]'s 2011 music video for "Mean" had a positive impact on the LGBTQ+ community. [0] performed during WorldPride NYC 2019 at the Stonewall Inn, a gay rights monument. [0] has donated to the LGBT organizations Tennessee Equality Project and GLAAD.A supporter of the March for Our Lives movement and gun control reform in the U.S., [0] is a vocal critic of white supremacy, racism, and police brutality. Following the George Floyd protests, [0] donated to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund and the Black Lives Matter movement, called for the removal of Confederate monuments in Tennessee, and advocated for Juneteenth to become a national holiday.In 2020, [0] urged her fans to check her fans's voter registration ahead of elections, which resulted in 65,000 people registering to vote within one day of [0]'s post, and endorsed Joe Biden and Kamala Harris in the U.S. presidential election. In spite of warnings that [0] might lose fans, [0] is an outspoken critic of former president Donald Trump and has expressed regret that [0] has not spoken up more often. [0] says that [0] wants to be "on the right side of history".
Cultural status.Public image: [0] is our person to focus on. Swift's music, life and image are points of attention in global celebrity culture. Critics regard [0] as a a rarely successful combination of a pop star and a singer-songwriter." [0] was labeled by the media in [0]'s early career as "America's Sweetheart" for [0]'s girl-next-door image. [0] has been a victim of numerous house break-ins and stalkers, some of whom were armed.

Wealth: [0] is our person to focus on. [0]'s net worth is estimated by Forbes and Bloomberg News at $1.1 billion as of October 2023, making [0] the first musician to achieve billionaire status "solely based on [0]'s songs and performances". Additionally, [0]'s publication rights over [0]'s first six albums were valued at $200 million in 2022. [0] has also developed a real estate portfolio worth $150 million as of October 2023, with properties in Nashville; Tribeca in Lower Manhattan, New York City; Los Angeles (Samuel Goldwyn Estate); and Rhode Island (High Watch).
Wealth.Philanthropy: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] is known for [0]'s philanthropic efforts. [0] ranked number one on DoSomething's 2015 "Gone Good" list, having received the Star of Compassion from the Tennessee Disaster Services and the Big Help Award from the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards for [0]'s "dedication to helping others" and "inspiring others through action". In 2008, [0] donated $100,000 to the Red Cross to help the victims of the Iowa flood. In 2009, [0] sang at BBC's Children in Need concert and raised £13,000 for the cause. [0] has performed at charity relief events, including Sydney's Sound Relief concert. In response to the May 2010 Tennessee floods, [0] donated $500,000 during a telethon hosted by WSMV.
